clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Glucose Monitoring Methods: Characterizing Glycemic Control in Subjects With Diabetes
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Glucose Monitoring Methods: Characterizing Glycemic Control in Subjects With Diabetes

collaborator.agency: International Diabetes Center at Park Nicollet

brief_summary.textblock: Evaluate the usefulness of continuous glucose monitoring devices in terms of their ability to identify periods throughout the day when glucose varies significantly.

detailed_description.textblock: Many CGM systems use a surrogate for blood glucose--tissue glucose or interstitial glucose. Interstitial fluid (ISF) is the medium for these approaches. A physiological lag in ISF glucose relative to capillary blood glucose has been noted, probably due to relatively low blood perfusion at the sampling site. 9 This physiological lag can result in an accuracy error, manifesting as a significant bias between blood and tissue glucose, particularly during periods of rapid glucose change. This lag error might be particularly meaningful when glucose is rapidly dropping towards hypoglycemia.

primary_outcome.measure: To collect sufficient glucose data by means of continuous glucose monitoring for the purpose of detecting clinically relevant alterations in blood glucose throughout a typical or modal day.

arm_group.description: People with type 1 or type 2 diabetes on insulin.

study_pop.textblock: adults with diabetes who are treated with insulin

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- adult
- A1c >7.4 within last 4 months
- type 1 or 2 diabetes treated with basal/bolus insulin
Exclusion Criteria:
- under 18 years of age
- unable to read/write english
- allergy to adhesives
- employee of CGM company
